contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox River | river_name = Obed River | image_name = Obed_river.jpg | caption = The Obed River at Alley Ford near [[Wartburg, Tennessee]] | origin = [[Cumberland County, Tennessee]]<br /> {{Coord|35.91867|-85.11301|type:landmark_region:US-TN|display=inline}} <ref name="GNIS">{{cite gnis|1303513|Obed River}}</ref> | mouth = [[Emory River]]<br /> {{Coord|36.07535|-84.64966|type:landmark_region:US-TN|display=title,inline}} | basin_countries = [[United States|USA]] | length = | mouth_elevation = 846 ft (258 m) <ref name="GNIS"/> | watershed_sqmi = 520 | watershed = <ref>{{Cite web| url=http://www.obedwatershed.org/files/Obed_Watershed.pdf| title=The Nature of the Obed River Watershed| publisher=Obed Watershed Community Association | page=3 |accessdate=October 5, 2011}}</ref> }} [[Image:Emoryrivermap.png|250px|right|thumb|The Emory/Obed drainage basin, located within the upper Tennessee drainage basin]] '''Obed River''' is a [[stream]] draining a part of the [[Cumberland Plateau]] in [[Tennessee]]. It, and particularly its tributaries, are important streams for [[whitewater]] enthusiasts. The Obed River rises in [[Cumberland County, Tennessee]], just south of [[Crossville, Tennessee|Crossville]]. It is bridged by [[U.S. Highway 70]] between downtown Crossville and the municipal [[airport]], and meets its confluence with the [[Little Obed River]] near a bridge on U.S. Highway 70N and an abandoned [[railroad]] bridge which was formerly part of the rail system linking [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] and [[Knoxville, Tennessee|Knoxville]]. Shortly thereafter, it is bridged by [[U.S. Highway 127]] and [[Interstate 40]]. Except during periods of very high flow, the stream is scarcely visible from these bridges because of the depth of its gorge. From there the stream enters a rather remote area. After several miles it is bridged by [[State Route 298 (Tennessee)|State Route 298]] (Genesis Road). From this point to its mouth it is designated as a "National Wild and Scenic River" along with Clear Creek and Daddys Creek.<ref name=NWSR>{{cite web |url = http://www.rivers.gov/wsr-obed.html |title = Obed River |publisher = National Wild and Scenic Rivers |accessdate = July 11, 2011 }}</ref> The direction of flow changes gradually from largely south to north to largely west to east. Shortly after crossing into [[Morgan County, Tennessee|Morgan County]] it receives the flow of Daddys Creek, which is a good whitewater rafting stream. Downstream from this is the mouth of Clear Creek. This stream is also part of the Obed River "Wild and Scenic" designation; like Daddys Creek, it too is a premiere whitewater stream during periods of high flow. Several miles below the mouth of Clear Creek is the confluence with the [[Emory River]]. Although the Obed River is the larger of the two, the river takes the name of the Emory River below the confluence. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.nps.gov/obed/planyourvisit/upload/OBEDmap1.pdf Access Map with putins and takeouts] * [http://www.nps.gov/obed/ Obed Wild and Scenic River] * [http://www.southeasternoutdoors.com/public-lands/national-parks/obed-river/obed-river-pictures.html Obed River Kayaking, Hiking & Climbing] * [http://www.paddletsra.org/ Tennessee Scenic Rivers Association (TSRA)] {{Protected_Areas_of_Tennessee}} [[Category:Rivers of Tennessee]] [[Category:Wild and Scenic Rivers of the United States]] [[Category:Protected areas of Cumberland County, Tennessee]] [[Category:Protected areas of Morgan County, Tennessee]] [[Category:United States National Park Service areas in Tennessee]]
